title: Building a culture of excellence | David Singleton (CTO of Stripe)
key_insights: Great names create discomfort initially - if your team is comfortable with a name, you probably don't have the right one yet
Look for polarization in team reactions as a sign of name strength, not consensus
Focus on behavior and experience rather than descriptive qualities when naming
Use the 'competitor test' - ask people how they'd react if a competitor launched with your proposed name
Generate 1,000+ name ideas before evaluating - suspend judgment and speculate on potential
The .com domain is less important now - it's become like an area code
Asymmetric and cumulative advantage come from distinctive names, not descriptive ones
Each letter of the alphabet has specific psychological associations and vibrancy levels

notable_companies: Various major corporations as clients including Microsoft, Intel, P&G

topics_discussed: The three-step naming process: identify, invent, implement
Creative team structure and disguised briefings
Client resistance to bold naming choices
Stories behind iconic names (Sonos, Azure, Pentium, Windsurf, Vercel)
AI company naming trends and challenges
Consumer vs. developer perspectives on AI
memorable_quotes: There is no power in comfort, not in the marketplace
If your team is comfortable with the name, chances are you don't have the name yet
You don't want to make a statement here. You want to start a story
summary: David Placek, founder of Lexicon Branding, shares the science behind creating powerful brand names, revealing why great names initially feel uncomfortable and providing practical frameworks for founders and product teams to develop distinctive names that create competitive advantage.
